ULTRAKILL is the only game where I can confidently say I have both rediscovered my love of gaming and blown out every blood vessel in my eyes like a Victorian orphan seeing electricity for the first time.

I booted it up expecting a retro shooter.
I left the first level feeling like I had been personally coached by a caffeinated archangel with anger issues.

This game doesn’t just encourage movement, it threatens your family if you stop.

I tried to take cover once.
V1 stared directly into my soul, whispered “COWARD,” and my monitor grew a fist and punched me.

The gameplay loop is simple:

1. Shoot

2. Slide

3. Punch a projectile back into someone’s colon at Mach 3

4. Surf on blood like it’s a morally questionable Slip ‘N Slide

5. Wonder why your heart rate is similar to a nuclear reactor’s

Story? Yes. It exists. It is delivered through environmental details, cryptic messages, and the distinct sensation that Hell has filed a restraining order against you.

Boss fights?
My therapist advised me not to talk about them.

Soundtrack?
My ceiling fan has been vibrating ever since I turned it up. My neighbor knocked and asked if I was “summoning something.”

Graphics?
Beautiful. Gorgeous. Like someone took the 1990s, set them on fire, and told you to parkour through the ashes.

Overall, ULTRAKILL has:
-taught me aggression
-redefined violence as a form of cardio
-and replaced my bloodstream with 100% pure adrenaline

10/10.
Buy it.
Become a war crime with legs.

Shoutout for that one person who meantioned Ultrakill at uni once just a year ago, and now my profane forms are getting grinded down across the stars almost every other day-off. Seriously, the game has been such a breath of fresh air for me this whole time—lore-wise, mechanics-wise, let alone the puzzles and something entirely new Dante had never implied, but I've been having the time of my life just thinking it through. I haven't been _that_ invested in any game with indie background for quite a while before Ultrakill, though it still has a lot to offer in the future. I wholeheartedly thank the devs for teaching me to cherish questionable graphics and to embrace the diversity of music and game soundtracks specifically!

A fast-paced shooter where you can toss coins that ricochet various projectiles all while parrying giant fists. I honestly love this game so much, and I've obviously played my fair share as is. 

The synergy found within the arsenal is impressive, but you know what else is impressive? The modded levels. If you can't find enough of a challenge within the main game, just remember that there's always more to play.

Lastly, the game is still in Early Access at the time of writing, which makes all of this even more interesting since there's still the promise of more to come. So by all means, give the game a try. If you can keep up with the pace, you won't regret a SECOND of it.

Even though Ultrakill is still technically unfinished, what is currently available has so much more polish and attention to detail than almost any other shooter in recent memory that it feels like a full release. The visuals are stylistically cohesive and detailed (especially on the overhauled levels), the music fits perfectly with the gameplay and levels, and the enemies all feel varied and unique. The base movement and weapons feel great but there is also an incredible amount of additional depth in weapon interactions and movement tech for those who want it. There's also a ton of replayability in each level and a surprising amount of additional content for an early access title. I absolutely cannot wait for the rest of the game to be released as each update has continued to improve on what is already my favorite shooter.

Sometimes you come across a game that is better than you, a game that your neurons cannot compute. For me this game is that. The game is still so good that that does not matter though, I have had to drop the difficulty lower than I would publicly admit to be able to actually play the game. I don't have the mechanical skill to keep up with the higher difficulties or ever use the coin gun. Please never add achievements. Game is way awesome though.

Amazing in any aspects ... gameplay, lore, soundtrack and atmosphere.
The game has great movement/physics, but also a unique take on the weapon system, its very satisfying to combine and experiment the different interaction in your arsenal.
While the game can be fast-paced and violent, its ambiance is also often incredibly deep and made me wander around levels just to contemplate the beauty of hell itself.

This is one of the games that inspired me to make games myself and gave me motivation.. knowing the story of its development.

This game, in ten minutes of pure crackhead-tier combat, gave me more fun than my last 100 hours of my "depression-core games" that I binge when I don't want to think too hard. It's an experience, and one that I cannot recommend hard enough. There will be moments where it seems unfair, where you just *cannot* get past this one boss, but if you fight through it and manage to eek past those moments of involuntary CBT, then you will get a game that delivers something truly special. The art direction and color usage is indicative of an intelligent dev team, the images so vivid at times that it feels like a fever dream, a cinematic shot out of one of the golden-age Disney movies, or a similar piece of hand-crafted art.

In the age of "live-service games" and Ubisoft-tier quality, a game like this really stands out. Kind of wish they would finish the last(?) arc of the game sooner though, it's been in development for a while, and I cannot guarantee that it won't pull a Project Zomboid and be in Early Access for 12+ years.

The music is thrilling and desperate, captures the lore and actions of the game well, one of the best composed soundtracks to me.

The gameplay of Ultrakill is so addictive and fun that even when I'm frustrated when I'm struggling I always end up coming back to this game. The variety in weaponry and how you can use them is also mindblowing. Even on standard difficulty if you become careless you'll end up dying, and I appreciate when a game doesn't hold your hand later in the game.

https://youtu.be/zjRkzC8c9Lo?si=tDzjm0MPICVM08L_

For a shooter that is supposed to be all about the SSStyle most enemies sure don´t react in any meaningful way to the majority of your shots. This means that the "player expression" is more of a facade than anything else as it pushes you to vary up your weapons for variety's sake and little else. The ranking is mostly superfluous aside from it helping with your hp regeneration, but even then the stylish part itself is not that engaging, at least in DMC, when you style on something you get to combo and lock down said enemies in the air as a result of your skills, but without significant stagger it loses much of its appeal.

Arena and boss design is similarly vapid due to this rigidity. With so little crowd control aside from the techniques to maximize dps, most enemy rooms turn into clusterfucks of projectiles where you spam the blood regen to tank the shots, and the bosses are mostly simplistic pattern memorization fights, where not even parries stops their onslaught, which makes such manoeuvres feel flaccid despite offering a lot of benefits in regenerating your health and dealing damage.

While not totally devoid of cool ideas as seen by the coin ricochets and some cool weapons, it is a game that has ridden more on its hype rather than the substance of its mechanics. The mark of amateurish design is to be seen everywhere, like how, for example, the game has secret collectables for you to pick up, but also simultaneously punishes you in your ranking for taking too long to explore the level. It is this lack of attention to detail and messy design that makes Ultrakill a gimmick rather than a true stepping stone for boomer shooters.

Look. I love this game. I think everyone should play it, but my god does the parry need to be changed in some way. It feels way too inconsistent to be reliable, ESPECIALLY when fighting Sysiphus Prime or othe quick enemies. It SHOULD be simple, I press F when I'm about to get hurt, and I heal and deal damage to them instead. However, this game is VERY STINGY on what counts as "in melee range" to the point where it is more frustrating than fun to use for me. It's only really viable against relatively slow projectiles, because trying to parry anything else feels like your trying to hit a bullseye with a blindfold on. I'm not asking for it to be easy; I'm just asking for it to be consistent (This isn't a git gud scenario either; I have p-ranked every base game level in the current game on violent, I know how this game works.)

Too easy, bosses can't even catch you if they are melee. Revolver doing 200% head shot just trivializes most enemies without a health bar, the same revolver than can be charged and just wipe rooms.
